pageContext.title: How to create valuable data science projects in the real world
pageContext.content:
Photo credit: Ion Chiosea / 123RF

In this post, I want to set out some guidelines on developing and carrying out effective and sustainable data science projects. I came up with this guide after making several mistakes in my own projects and seeing others make their own.

Some may not apply to all data scientists because not all of this will fall into their remit. However, I‚Äôve been in a team where we didn‚Äôt have the luxury of having a dedicated business analyst, product manager, or even a data science manager. I had to take on some of the responsibilities myself, and I often did not do a great job.

But it was a valuable learning experience and here are some of the things that I‚Äôve learned.

What questions should be addressed for a project to be considered successful?

When coming up with a solution to a problem, I find it useful to picture what success looks like. This helps me develop strategies to get to the end goal. (Here, we‚Äôre assuming that we already know what the problem is. But don‚Äôt underestimate how hard it can be for you and your team to identify a problem.)

If I can answer the following questions adequately and immediately, then the project is likely to be successful.

  1. Why are you doing the project? What value does the project bring and how does it contribute to the wider data science team‚Äôs goals?
  2. Who are the main stakeholders?
  3. What is the current solution to the problem?
  4. Is there a simple and effective solution that can be performed quickly?
  5. Have you made an effort to involve the right people with enough notice and information?
  6. Have you sense-checked your solution with someone else?
  7. Have you made an effort to ensure that the code is robust?
  8. Have you made an effort to make sure that the project can be easily understood and handed over to someone else?
  9. How are you validating your model in production?
  10. How are you gathering feedback?

This list may be far from exhaustive (depending on the project), but it‚Äôs at least a good starting point.

The steps below help in addressing each of these questions.

A 5-step guideline for data science¬†projects

1. Get an initial evaluation of the project‚Äôs potential value

Why do it?

You should be able to adequately explain why one project should be completed before another. It also allows you to understand how the project aligns with the goals of the team and the company. This will also somehow guide you on what metric to optimize for the model.

What does this involve?

A rough quantification of benefits (e.g. monetary savings, increase in revenue, less time spent on manual labor).

The argument against this is that it‚Äôs hard to do and is not always quantifiable. My response is: If you or your stakeholders can‚Äôt figure out the value of the project, then why are you wasting your time? The value doesn‚Äôt have to be perfect; a ballpark estimate will do.

This step also involves determining who the main stakeholders are.

What happens if it‚Äôs not done?

We may spend ages doing a project that no one benefits from.

Our data science team was tasked with producing a list of people who were most likely to benefit from being contacted by our marketing team. A model was built, but we decided to spend a couple of months improving it.

Despite the new model giving better results, the team had to adjust their threshold because the business didn‚Äôt care about the scores generated for each customer. Instead, they wanted to make sure they were contacting a fixed number of people. The time spent improving the model was pointless, and we would‚Äôve known this if we scoped the project better.

What is the outcome from this step?

A rough quantitative estimate of the project‚Äôs value or an executive summary.

2. Determine the current approach or create a baseline¬†model

Photo credit: Rama Ramakrishnan

Why do it?

The current approach gives us a benchmark to target. All useful models should beat the current approach.

If there is no current solution to the problem, then you should develop a baseline model. The baseline model is essentially the solution to the problem without machine learning. It‚Äôs likely that a complex solution may only provide incremental value, so you‚Äôll need to evaluate if it‚Äôs actually worth building anything more complex.

What does this involve?

Speak to stakeholders to determine what they do currently. It‚Äôs likely they don‚Äôt measure their success rate, so it‚Äôs something that you‚Äôll have to calculate.

Building a baseline model should be fairly quick and rudimentary, probably using counting methods.

What is the outcome of this phase?

  • A baseline evaluation number of the performance required
  • An assessment of whether a complex model is worth building

What happens if not done?

You could waste time building a complex model.

We missed this when we built our recommendation engine. We didn‚Äôt check that the algorithm was better than a sensible baseline (recommending the most popular content). It could‚Äôve been that the recommendation algorithm didn‚Äôt provide enough value to warrant doing it when we did.

3. Have a team discussion

Why do it?

It‚Äôs easy to think that you know what you need on your own, but having discussions with others can highlight things you‚Äôve missed or could be improved. Don‚Äôt underestimate the importance of having people with different viewpoints contribute to the discussion.

What does it involve?

Speak to at least one other data scientist and show them the results you‚Äôve obtained so far. Perhaps, they have ideas about how you can improve on your idea. It‚Äôs vital you do this before you start on the model because you‚Äôll be less likely to change your model once it‚Äôs written.

Also, the data scientist you speak to might be the one doing your code review. This will help them with context. Speak to the engineer that will be involved in productionizing your work. They‚Äôll likely need to know what to expect and may have suggestions that will make productionizing the code much easier.

What is the outcome of this phase?

Nothing concrete! Just something to ensure quality is as good as it can be first time round. Ensure that the relevant people are aware and onboard with the project.

What happens if not done?

You may miss important things. Some typical problems include:

  • Unmanageable transfer and handling of storage files when the model is moved into production
  • Model output misses the mark and isn‚Äôt in the most useful form

This was the case with one of the models I produced. I wrote code that made multiple API calls, many of which were unnecessary. It was fine on a small dataset, which I ran locally, but the servers struggled with the load in production. It wasn‚Äôt fixed until I spoke to an engineer that helped me diagnose the problem.

4. Model development

Photo credit: Hortonworks

Why do it?

This is the model that we use to ultimately solve the problem.

What does it involve?

It‚Äôs not only about creating a model. It‚Äôs important to emphasize some steps that should be carried out to produce high-quality production code.

In the development process, you should be doing regular code reviews. Remember that you are likely not the only one that sees the code and are invested in the project‚Äôs success, so there should be good code documentation. There will almost certainly be bugs and unexpected inputs in production, so you can mitigate these issues by performing code testing to improve the code‚Äôs robustness.

What is the outcome of this phase?

  • A shared repository (GitHub) with the required files
  • A working model that solves the problem

What happens if not done?

The model has to be completed, otherwise the problem won‚Äôt be solved. If your code isn‚Äôt tested, there‚Äôll be mistakes with logic that may go unnoticed until production. If the code isn‚Äôt reviewed by someone else or documented, it‚Äôll be difficult for other people to take over when you leave the company or are on leave.

5. Model monitoring and¬†feedback

Why do it?

This is to ensure that our product works as intended. The outputs of the solution should be stable and reliable. We should be the first to know if something is wrong.

This is especially the case when the stakeholders begin questioning our data. We‚Äôre in the business of providing value to the company so we should also be measuring the impact that our solutions have. Is it working? Does it need tweaking? How much money are we generating? How frequently is the solution being used? These are the numbers we can report to the executives to show the value data science is contributing to the business.

What does it involve?

This involves a period of time (perhaps a couple of weeks) after the model has been put into production to manually and proactively check that everything is working. This also involves automating the monitoring process. Perhaps, create a dashboard, automated email alerts, and/or an anomaly detection system.

For feedback purposes, this can involve discussing with the stakeholder how you‚Äôll receive feedback. Will it be qualitative or quantitative?

What is the outcome of this phase?

  • Methods and products to ensure that the model is working properly
  • Feedback on the usage and value of the solution

What happens if not done?

If we don‚Äôt monitor our products properly, we could risk losing the stakeholders‚Äô trust in the things we build. It could also cost the business a lot of money and time trying to fix the problem.

One example I‚Äôve faced is when the data in the analytics tool we built started giving wildly incorrect figures. It turns out that the provider of the raw data had messed up. It was our stakeholders that picked up on the problem before our data team did. Robust testing and automated alerting should‚Äôve picked it up, but we didn‚Äôt have that in place.

Additionally, if we‚Äôre not getting feedback, then we have no idea how useful our projects are or whether they‚Äôre still being used. In a meeting with the marketing team, we had to ask, ‚ÄúAre you using the model?‚Äù We should never have to ask that because we should have scoped the project properly during steps 1 and 2, and we should‚Äôve done the monitoring as part of the project, not in an unrelated meeting.

***

Realistically, you don‚Äôt need to follow all of these steps to create a successful data science project. It‚Äôs more likely that you‚Äôll have to weigh which of these things are worth doing.

I‚Äôm very aware that I‚Äôm not the most experienced data scientist. So, if anyone has any comments, questions, or suggestions, please feel free to fire away in the comments. Thank you for reading. üôÇ
